replies.bodyText: How is it a serialized form of world border? It's used to serialize it, sure, but that class itself isn't a serialized form, since, well, it's a class
replies.author: 2xsaiko

replies.bodyText: Properties is an acceptable name. This class is, in essence, an immutable pojo while world border is mutable instead. a world border is converted back and forth to this, and this is written/read to/from nbt.
replies.author: liach

timeline.bodyText:
Suggested change

we have "roofed forest" and imo this is a good term
timeline.author: liach

replies.bodyText: They're called dark forests as of 1.13, and the names are for totally different reasons (canopies versus the tops of caves) so I don't see why this precedent should be followed.
replies.author: haykam821

replies.bodyText: Then ceilinged, hasCeiling doesn't match the naming style really
replies.author: liach

replies.bodyText: hasCeiling is just fine and sounds a lot better than ceilinged.
replies.author: Juuxel

replies.bodyText: How about skyObstructed
replies.author: liach

replies.bodyText: I'm in favor of hasCeiling. Typically you talk about the ceiling of a cave rather than its roof and ceilinged is simply wrong.
replies.author: haykam821

replies.bodyText: hasCeiling is a wrong term. Had you use hasCeiling for a field in a pojo, spring framework or so will generate accessors like isHasCeiling which shows hasCeiling makes no sense for a name of a boolean field. Boolean field names should be adjective or adjective phrases, not verb phrases.
replies.author: liach

replies.bodyText: There is nothing wrong with hasCeiling here, both is and has are okay prefixes for booleans. How does spring have anything to do with this?
replies.author: coderbot16

replies.bodyText: liach, I'm sure we've had this discussion about prefixing boolean fields with "has" before. The yarn style guide advises against verb phrases in fields, but it's only a guide, and especially when the alternative sounds like broken English, "has..." works fine for boolean fields. As an English speaker "has..." feels a bit like an adjective phrase anyway, even if it grammatically isn't - it specifies an attribute of the object.
replies.author: Earthcomputer

replies.bodyText: This probably is fine since there is hasSkylight
replies.author: liach

timeline.author: liach

timeline.bodyText: GeneratorOptions$WorldGeneratorType. The name is too obtuse, needs to be optimized
timeline.author: liach

timeline.bodyText: How is level type different from world generator type etc?
timeline.author: liach

replies.bodyText: We spent like half an hour deciding what to name these three classes. This is called LevelType, because it maps directly to the level-type field in server.properties. MapType is called that because that's the localization string of the button that controls that setting (although it was still unclear to us how that button showed options that are not in the MapType enum but are in LevelType like Large Biomes. WorldGeneratorType is used in the buffet generator. Maybe BuffetWorldGeneratorType is actually a better name for that one.
replies.author: 2xsaiko

replies.bodyText: That client button appears to me as a fancy layer above the actual level type (this boi) that is used in actual save. Mojang does offer some sort of shortcut for powerful maneuvers on client
replies.author: liach

timeline.bodyText: Seriously, ServerWorldProperties, don't sneak in your trashy names
timeline.author: liach

replies.bodyText:
problem is that now we have WorldProperties and LevelProperties describing the same construct. The impl of levelproperties is a big mess of interfaces like World, except iirc most of them aren't used anywhere.
Context is important!
replies.author: TheGlitch76

replies.bodyText: I'd say this specific category may work better in a specific pr we can bikeshed
replies.author: i509VCB

replies.bodyText: WorldProperties is the properties of a world, LevelProperties is level.dat and is both a WorldProperties and a SaveProperties. Simple as that.
replies.author: liach

replies.bodyText: @i509VCB I've opened #1337 for debate, yet no one comes and just explains in this comment thread. I am pretty sure I've asked people to look into my debate issue yet no one seems to care yet, so 🤷 cannot do anything
replies.author: liach
